title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [20 june 1867]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [20 June 1867]
text: 20 June 1867thursdayThursday 10 oclocko'clock My dear Walti received your letter yesterday with the 10 dollrdollar and the one on fridayFriday with the 2 i shall keep the ten to move with it comes very good we shall move the last of juneJune so walt you can send your next weeksweek's letter the same as this and after that i will write how to direct) i am glad Walt you keep well that is the greatest blessing after all) i fellfeel quite smart considering i have to work so very hard i feel when i lie down at night as if i should not be able to get up in the morning but when morning comes i feel better matty and sis has gone to woodbridgeWoodbridge new jersey near perth amboyPerth Amboy to see if she can get board i dontdon't much expect she will get any place but would be very glad if she does she is not very well and the young ones never was half so much trouble i dontdon't think in their lives as they are now their mother says she dontdon't know what to doodo with them matty worked on the machine and has had a bad coughfcough i think her working on the machine so steady hurt her i wanted her to stop but she wanted to get so much done but she is much better now only has a slight coughf)cough) george is at work on the new main as they call it as inspector i beleivebelieve that sthat's what they call it he stands it midlingmiddling well it is standing and walking but yesterday he had to walk very far to get here he was where he couldentcouldn't ride his legs troubles him some get lame he was here to breakfast this morning but felt as if he would like to loaf and live at his ease there was no particular need as i told him of his going to work so soon but he seemed inclined to doodo so i shall be glad when i get down town on his account it is so far up here he has had a wonderfullwonderful appetite after being sick but itsit's not so good now but that is nothing strange his face dontdon't appear to bloat any more we have letters from Jeff quite often he worries very much about matti and the children and mammy i told mat to not write every thing to worry him it would doodo us no good but you know how mat is she has certainly not had a beginning of work to doodo but she has felt not very well and very fretfulfretful it is amusing to see the folks wachwatch us to see if we make any preperationspreparations to move but nary a word doodo they speak i dontdon't think they would be quite so bad if mrs beecher hadenthadn't given them directions the other day the girl went out and they tied one door with a rope and locked the other edd went down to get a pail of water but couldentcouldn't get in i told him to go to the hydrant matt said he shouldentshouldn't so she went down stairs and got the key i should move if the place was finished as small as it is but it has to be painted and it would be so bad but i think i would be very much better ofoff there than here the place has had very many improvements good bie Walter deari am very sorry for the OconnorsO'Connors very indeed Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [20 June 1867]
